ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Kandice Lyn Harper  Kandice was great. Very responsive and helpful.
Instructor: Kandice Lyn Harper  Kandice was very helpful and always available to answer questions.
Instructor: Kandice Lyn Harper  Kandice.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Some of the class seemed a little basic. I didn't feel like the readings offered much new info for anyone who had a background in biology or has taken other water courses. I do like reading journal articles to see the most recent research.
The course was excellent and I very much enjoyed it!
This is one of the few oceanography courses available to F&ES graduate students, and is an excellent overview of the physical and biological processes of the ocean.

I thought some of the readings were too basic and were repetitive for students who had coastal ecosystems (L& Parsons). I would also recommend Denny's Oceanography textbook (how the ocean works). It's well-written and covers most of the topics we reviewed in class. And cheaper than the eChapters.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trips!I also liked the paper/presentation assignment (for myself, because it gave me a chance to research a topic I am interested in).
The field trips were exciting and helped enforce course material very well. The lectures were engaging, and I enjoyed learning about a variety of topics related to biological oceanography.
The range of topics we covered was very interesting and helpful.
The field trips were my favorite part. It was great to interact with government researchers working on these issues.
I think the videos were incredibly helpful (Scripts tank experiment etc).

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Maybe move through material quicker.
I thought the course was great, and cannot think of any improvements. It was organized and well-run.

I didn't buy the Garrison book, because as a student, if I am going to spend money on a book I'd rather buy a paper book or have free access to online material. I wish I had bought the Garrison chapters in the beginning, but I wasn't sure how necessary it would be. Some aspects of the course seemed a little disorganized, and a reference text book would have been useful.

I think given that FES has so few marine/coastal classes it would be great if they could coordinate so they compliment each other without repeating each other. Particuarly with coastal ecosystems, this class was a good extension of that - but it would have been even more valuable without the redundancies.Also I think student presentations are great, but it would be better to just have 1 a class period. Maybe one idea would be to have a presentation at the beginning or middle of the lecture? Then that would make everyone pay more attention to presentations and would break up the lectures. Also I think there's space in the syllabus to cover a few more topics (migratory species? Corals? Mangroves? High latitude ecosystems? Seasonal variations? More on fisheries?)

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There were not that many labs but they were relevant.
The lecture matched the lab session on plankton well, so I thought that worked great.
I dont think the plankton lab should be a whole class period.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Kandice did a great job of sending us our assignment reminders and coordinating the field trip logistics. She didn't contribute much to the content/substance of the class, so that might be an area for potential involvement in the future.
Excellent all around.
Instructor: Kandice Lyn Harper  I didn't really interact with her much - but she was always responsive and helpful if I had a question.
Instructor: Kandice Lyn Harper  Kandice was very helpful in always being available for questions and organizing class field trips.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It fits in with my general interest.
This course is pivotal to my studies improving coastal water resources and I am extremely glad I had the opportunity to take it.

I am interested in marine issues and Mary Beth is one of the few professors who offer a course in that field. I only wish she could have a graduate only level course. We need more courses on this topic.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: sounded interesting.
I wanted to learn more about marine resources and ways to improve them for the future.
It is one of the few marine-related courses at F&ES, and it covers fisheries, which I am particularly interested in. I would like to have learned more about fisheries.
I'm interested in oceanography, climate and marine issues. This class checks all those boxes. For people who have taken Shimi's coastal class, this will be easy(but just new enough).

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I wouldhave liked to learn more about current research.
Yes, indeed.
Yes!
Yes, I really liked the course and field trips in particular. I think overall it was too easy though.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I really liked the fisheries exercise.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would ask how much of a background do they have in the topic already.
I would advise to ask any questions you have often and review the material frequently to help absorb it better.

Download the Garrison textbook chapters, and stay on top of downloading the readings throughout the semester. Professor Decker doesn't directly reference the readings, so it is unclear how relevant they are, but they really help with strengthening the understanding of the material.
It's great and interesting. Good 5th class.
